title: floats can't be negative in schema
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

If you define an addon parameter as a float in config.json under schema, you are unable to change the value in the UI to a negative number.

If you set the default value of a parameter to a negative number you will get an error trying to load the plugin.

Integers seem to handle negative numbers just fine.

I am trying to add a negative float for a geographical coordinate.

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.10.0

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

6.4

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.9.7

### Steps to reproduce the issue

Scenario one - cannot have a negative number when creating the add-on.
1. Create a new addon with an option set to a negative value.
2. In the schema try to specify a negative number as the min. for the option.
3. Try to load the addon.  You should get an error.

Scenario two - cannot change a number defined as a float to a negative value.
1. Define a float in the schema without min/max values.
2. Start the addon.  Try to enter a negative number in the Configuration screen for the addon.  You will be unable to type in the "-" symbol.



### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
Text is gone now, but there was something about matching a regular expression string.
```


### Additional information

Scenario two is easy to reproduce.  Scenario one was bugging me for days but I can't reproduce it any longer.

title: Locally built addons updates leave previous images (same as #160 from 2017)
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

When an addon builds locally on HA, it does not removes previously built images. This can accumulates to many Go over time. The only way is to remove them manually with "docker image prune -a", but this also deletes images of non running but still relevant containers.

Here are several examples : 
- https://github.com/alexbelgium/hassio-addons/issues/58
- https://community.home-assistant.io/t/unused-containers-images-not-deleted-by-hass-io/23866
- https://community.home-assistant.io/t/disk-almost-full/121023

This was addressed here but is still occurring : https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/issues/160

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.10.0

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

6.4

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

2021.10.0

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Install a locally built addon
2. Update this addon to a new version
3. Check with portainer or any docker tool that the previous image was not removed

When running this way for several months, I gave several gigaoctets of unused images.


### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
No relevant info
```

title: Devices not mapped into the addon?
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

I've one addon that needs access to the `/dev/sda` device. It was configured like this:
```json
"privileged": ["SYS_ADMIN", "SYS_RAWIO"],
"devices": ["/dev/sda"],
```
and this was working. But since some update (I don't know exactly what, because it was only detected after I rebooted the host machine, it was working fine until then) it does not work. I have not changed nothing.

Using the `portainer` addon, if I inspect the container of my addon I can't see the `devices` being mapped:
```json
   "Devices": null,
```
I don't know if they must appear here or Home Assistant uses another way to map devices to the container, but is strange to me.

If I enable `full_access` it works, but I suppose the objective of the `devices` is not need to use this `full_access`.

Am I right and the mapping must appear when inspecting the container?


  
  


### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.09.6

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

6.4

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.10.1

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. add `devices` to the configuration addon
2. try to access them in the addon or look at the inspect in the portainer addon


### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt

title: Device access changed in addon
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

I don't know if this is a bug, or something that has changed in the latest version.

I'm one of the developers of HDD Tools, an addon that looks at the smart data of the disk. Basically it executes a `smartctl` command and sends this info as sensor. More info: https://github.com/Draggon/hassio-hdd-tools/

Until now, I had this options in the ```config.json``` of the addon (this is only the relevant part):
```json
{
  "name": "HDD Tools",
...
  "privileged": ["SYS_ADMIN", "SYS_RAWIO"],
...
  "options": {
      "hdd_path": "/dev/sda",
...
  },
  "schema": {
      "hdd_path": "device(subsystem=block)",
...
    }
}
```

With this, it seemed that Home Assistant added permisions for the hdd `/dev/XXXXX` selected by the user in the config without problem. But now, I don't know since when this does not work anymore, more info here: https://github.com/Draggon/hassio-hdd-tools/issues/35 

I know that adding a `full_access: true` fixes the issue, but the score of the addon goes down to 1 and it seems more clean to me like it was until now. 

This is a bug or simply this way of doing the things has changed and I need to ask for `full_access` in a mandatory way?

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.09.6

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

6.4

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.9.7

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Install the HDD Tools addon
2. Execute it
3. Look at the logs


### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
21-10-04 09:32:29 ERROR (SyncWorker_5) [supervisor.docker.addon] Add-on HDD Tools try to access to blocked device sda!
```


### Additional information

I don't know if this is an issue of the supervisor or it belongs to other part.

title: Supervisor permenantly stuck in CoreState.STARTUP
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

After attempting to restart core, home assistant supervisor has become permenantly stuck in ``CoreState.STARTUP``.

Core does not start and supervisor is permenantly stuck such that even ``ha os reboot`` does not fix it, the system does reboot resetting `uptime` but cannot get out of ``STARTUP``.

All operations such as stopping or restarting core are blocked.

```txt
21-09-28 22:38:51 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.jobs] 'OSManager.update' blocked from execution, system is not running - CoreState.STARTUP
21-09-28 23:44:53 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.jobs] 'Supervisor.restart' blocked from execution, system is not running - CoreState.STARTUP
21-09-29 00:16:25 ERROR (MainThread) [supervisor.utils] Can't execute stop while a task is in progress
21-09-29 00:23:15 ERROR (MainThread) [supervisor.utils] Can't execute restart while a task is in progress
```


I believe this issue is the same as #2519; that issue was closed without resolution.

Is there a way to reset the CoreState or debug what is causing it to stall out?

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.09.4

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

6.4

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.9.7

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1.  Restart Core
2.  Supervisor toasts itself and won't leave `CoreState.STARTUP` blocking all further operations
3.
...

title: OS Upgrade Failure from 5.0 to 6.2
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

I installed the last successful installable version: hassos_rpi2-5.0.img.gz for my rpi 2. Any image version beyond this, my rpi 2 doesn't respond (nothing running when I connect a screen via hdmi).
Now in v5.0, I am not able to install any add-ons "'AddonManager.install' blocked from execution, system is not healthy".
 When I click update via supervisor for newest version 6.2 nothing happens and I can't access it anymore.

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.08.dev2601

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

HassOS 5.0

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.8.8

### Steps to reproduce the issue

Approach 1:
1. Download and install image from: https://github.com/home-assistant/operating-system/releases/download/5.0/hassos_rpi2-5.0.img.gz
2. Write the image in sd card using Balena Etcher.
3. Insert SD card in rpi 2, connect ethernet cable, plug on.
4. Not able to recover via snapshot (as of v4.19) so start a new login.
5. Goto supervisor->dashboard click update from 5.0 to 6.2
6. No response!


1. Tried above steps with latest version: https://github.com/home-assistant/operating-system/releases/download/6.2/haos_rpi2-6.2.img.xz
2. After step 3, no response  (nothing running when I connect a screen via hdmi)!

Tried all above steps with my last working version v4.19 thereafter following step 5 above, same issue.

title: Supervisor broken again
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

As I described in issue #54559
[https://github.com/home-assistant/core/issues/54559](url)


After while, when manipulating with some addons (Grafana,Influx,) or just try to update something in supervisor panel, then everything stop working. Also cannot restart HomeAssistant, cannot go to (Grafana,Influx,) or to Supervisor panel. Few minutes working just dashboards with actual data (temp, pressure etc...) after +/- 10 minutes stopped working also whole home assistant and says "Unable to connect". When clean browser cache then didn't find site.

I think it could be something with docker ? Maybe network, but on same network I have Synology NAS and it's working perfectly.

I suppose that this log didn't help, because it's started after whole system going down...
Its dig from microSD card, because access to HomeAssistant is impossible, SSH down, port 8123 also debug 4357 is also impossible to connect, only ping to Raspberry working.

title: Misconfigured network after reconnecting
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

It seems that the way networks are configured, when device gets disconnected from wlan and reconnects, then the virtual network created for home assistant takes precedence as a gateway (has lower metric), resulting in no internet connection.

The solution (workaround?) for me was to manually add (in cron job) route with proper gateway and metric `=0` whenever wifi is reconnected:
```
/usr/sbin/route add -net default gw 192.168.50.1 netmask 0.0.0.0 dev wlan0 metric 0
```

Not sure what should be the proper/idiomatic solution but probably docker network created by home assistant probably should never become the default gateway for network connection.

I've added a few more debug details in the community thread [here](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/networkmanager-gets-connected-to-wifi-but-no-internet/326161/2)

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.06.8

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant Supervised

### Which operating system are you running on?

Debian

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Linux 10 (buster)

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.7.4

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Shut down wifi router
2. Restart wifi
3. Wait for network manager to reconnect 
4. Observe that `ping -c4 8.8.8.8` results in `From 169.254.117.211 icmp_seq=1 Destination Host Unreachable`
5. See that `route -n` has the lowest metric value for `veth*` interface rather than `wlan`


### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
Not applicable
```

title: Invalid Add-On Repository  / DNS Issue?
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

Hello,

I cannot grasp the Background of this Issue and (in my beginner Opinion) Homeassistant doesnt really show me that much information so I am opening an Issue because I cannot really diagnose anything here. 

Basically every new repository I want to add I get the Error Message "Invalid Add-on repository!". This happens with some of the Repositories I tried in the last few weeks, for example:

https://github.com/jm-73/Indego
https://github.com/fondberg/spotcast
https://github.com/Apipa169/Assistant-Relay-for-Hassio

Weirdly enough, the last Link works. 


I have tried to restart the System (Host) then adding it, I have disabled my DuckDNS Access, I have tried to change the DNS Server over SSH (CLI) to 8.8.8.8 via "ha dns options --servers dns://8.8.8.8". Nothing changes. I have read some other posts that stated that DNS is falsely setup. My router uses the standard Telekom DNS.

Whats also interesting, although I dont know if that has anything to do with this issue, if I try to "Manually install" the addons by dragging them into the custom_components folder, they are not installed after I restart the host. 

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.06.8 (beta)

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Home Assistant OS 6.1

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.7.4

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Paste the Link in the HACS Repositories section 
2. Try to Add repository
3. Voila: "Invalid Add-on repository!"
...

title: Firefox: 401: Unauthorized / No valid ingress session None
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

I am no longer able to display the Web UI of Add-Ons such as Node-Red, File Editor, Portainer, SQLite Web, etc.

Clicking "Open Web UI" results in this message:
```text
401: Unauthorized
```

Supervisor's log reports:
```text
21-07-21 15:31:24 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.api.ingress] No valid ingress session None
```



### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.06.8

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant Supervised

### Which operating system are you running on?

Debian

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

2021.7.2

### Steps to reproduce the issue

Unknown.


### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
21-07-21 15:31:24 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.api.ingress] No valid ingress session None
```


### Additional information

I normally access Home Assistant via one of three devices (using the same admin-level account):

1. Android tablet with MS Edge. This device has displayed the `401: Unauthorized message` for a long time. I was never able to fix it but it didn't matter because the tablet was impractical for using Node-Red.

2. Ubuntu laptop with Firefox. This device is my daily driver for maintaining Home Assistant and now it cannot display the web UI of various Add-Ons, notably Node-Red, File Editor, Portainer, etc.

3. Windows desktop with MS Edge. This one is still able to display the web UI of Add-Ons.

I don't know what causes this problem so everything I have tried is a shot in the dark (and none of it has worked):
- Refresh browser page
- Delete refresh tokens
- Reboot host machine

title: Auto-Update doesn't work (schema is not compatible)
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

Auto update does not update add-ons that have updates available despite those add-ons having the auto-update switch turn on.

This issue has existed for some time, recently I mistakenly opened a ticket relating to ZwaveJS (home-assistant/addons#2101) as that addon is frequently out of date (because it has a frequent release interval). 

A few days ago I noticed that my DuckDNS addon now has an update available (1.12.5 -> 1.13.0).

Searching I see a comment (https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/issues/2643#issuecomment-787444960) by ludeeus that supervisor should be applying auto-updates every 16hrs after it starts.

I'm unsure exactly how to determine the uptime on supervisor (`ha supervisor stats` doesn't track it), however the system uptime is over 14 days and core is over 3 days, the DuckDNS addon has been out of date for at least 3 days.   

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.06.8

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Home Assistant OS 6.1

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.7.3

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Install any addon (zwavejs seems most frequent to update)
2. Enable `Auto update` on said addon
3. Wait for a new release of said addon
4. Wait 16hours after to allow supervisor to run it's auto-update task
5. Obeserve addon still out-of-date
...

title: 'AddonManager.update' blocked from execution, no host internet connection
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

On Supervisor reload internet connection is good enough - no errosrs:
```
21-07-15 17:21:28 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.updater] Fetching update data from https://version.home-assistant.io/stable.json
HA manage to get list of updates (show available new versions), but fails to proceed with actual add-on update:
21-07-15 17:21:49 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.jobs] 'AddonManager.update' blocked from execution, no host internet connection
```

Supervisor getting list of new versions and show available updates in UI.
But fails to proceed with actual update.


After full HOST restart - Supervisor managed to update one add-on.
Next day message 
```
'AddonManager.update' blocked from execution, no host internet connection

title: Updating Home Assistant image failed
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

Supervisor fails to update components (Core and/or Supervisor).

Possibly related issue: #2972

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.06.8

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Home Assistant OS 6.1

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.6.6

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Open Supervisor panel (Dashboard)
2. Click `Update`
3. On the update dialog, either enable or disable `Snapshot` and click `Update`
4. Snapshot will be created (if enabled), then an "Unknown error" is displayed stating to check the Supervisor logs.

After a few tries, it works. I *think* it might have something to do with not allowing enough time to download the docker image before trying to install it.

title: HA DNS issues when using local resolver / unwanted failover to cloudflare dns
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

When HA is behind a firewall and the firewall also hosts DNS services, HA fails to perform DNS queries successfully.  This is true when the only configured DNS is the local DNS.  This is especially apparent when firewall blocks all outbound DNS.  HA becomes sluggish.

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.06.3

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Home Assistant OS 6.0

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.6.4

### Steps to reproduce the issue

Configure HA network settings in GUi to use local firewall for DNS.
Ensure no other DNS services are configured by issuing "dns reset" from HA cli.
Verify DNS by issuing "dns info" 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/51183445/122497648-bbb57f00-cfbb-11eb-81d7-23671f9ab330.png)

Firewall logs still show HA reaching out to 1.1.1.1 and 1.0.0.1 on tcp/53 and tcp/853 even though cloudflare dns is not configured anywhere on the system.

System exhibits slow and sluggish behavior due to the unpermitted cloudflare dns traffic.

title: Add-ons missing - Official and 3rd party
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

Addons from the official store and from 3rd parties hosted on github.com disappeared.  This occurs under 5.11, 5.12 and now 6.x.  This was a clean install around 3 months ago on a RP4.  Supervisor complains it can find guthub.com.  Dropping to the CLI and doing an nslookup or ping of github.com fails.  Other random sites seem to complete successfully.  Added static entries to the docker container via CLI, name resolution then succeeds.  Still can't add official store or 3rd part stores, supervisor still complains.  A complete system shutdown and restart of the OS occasionally brings back official store.  Official store will occasionally come back but then disappear again after 24 ~48 hours.  Upgraded to OS 6.x and so far official store has stayed visible for over 24 hours but still can't add 3rd part stores back.

title: content-trust=false option fails to work correctly
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

- Prior to version 2021.5.4, setting `content-trust=false` allowed for Supervisor source code modifications. The instance was simply flagged as `unsupported`.

- In version 2021.5.4, the same setting results in the instance flagged as `unsupported` _and_ `unhealthy`. In other words, regardless of whether `content-trust` is set to `true` or `false`, it produces the same result when it detects source code modifications.


The `content-trust` option was suggested to me by frenck when I asked for a way to allow for modifying Supervisor's source code (a trivial patch that changes two integer values to reduce the polling frequency of connectivity/version checks).
https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/issues/2863#issuecomment-835604541

As far back as 2021.4.3, it worked perfectly but now, in 2021.5.4, it makes no difference if `content-trust` is `true` or `false`, the result is the same when it detects Supervisor source code modifications.

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.05.4

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant Supervised

### Which operating system are you running on?

Debian

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.6.0

### Steps to reproduce the issue


1. Make a trivial change to Supervisor's source code. For example, in `tasks.py` change the integer value on [line 50](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/64c59d0fe92bbc48f206cfaff3ed2709099c7a6a/supervisor/misc/tasks.py#L50) from `30` to `300`. On [line 456](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/64c59d0fe92bbc48f206cfaff3ed2709099c7a6a/supervisor/misc/tasks.py#L456), change it from `600` to `3600`.

2.  Restart Supervisor. The log will report the detected source code modifications and the instance will be flagged as `unsupported` and `unhealthy`.

3. Execute: `sudo ha supervisor options --content-trust=false`

4. Restart Supervisor. The log fails to mention anything about `content-trust` being disabled and the instance will still be flagged as `unsupported` and `unhealthy` (prior to 2021.5.4 the log would mention that content-trust was disabled and the instance would only be flagged as `unsupported`).


### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
Log supplied in the next section (see below).
```


### Additional information


When the following command is executed:
```text
sudo ha supervisor options --content-trust=false
```
Supervisor's log reports:

```text
21-06-03 18:16:53 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.evaluate] Starting system evaluation with state CoreState.RUNNING
21-06-03 18:16:53 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.evaluations.source_mods] Disabled content-trust, skipping evaluation
21-06-03 18:16:53 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.evaluations.base] Clearing UnsupportedReason.SOURCE_MODS as reason for unsupported
21-06-03 18:16:53 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.evaluations.base] System run with disabled trusted content security. (more-info: https://www.home-assistant.io/more-info/unsupported/content_trust)
21-06-03 18:16:53 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.evaluate] System evaluation complete
```
The log's third line suggests Supervisor acknowledges `content-trust=false` and it has cleared the `unsupported` flag. However, the UI shows the instance is still flagged as `unsupported` and `unhealthy`.
![Screenshot from 2021-06-03 14-18-50](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/44732909/120697997-6d14ca80-c47c-11eb-931a-24879bf1eb23.png)

In addition, _restarting_ Supervisor doesn't clear either of the two flags. In fact, after a restart, Supervisor's log implies it has _forgotten_ about `content-trust=false` because there's no reference to it in the log (prior versions would mention content-trust was disabled on startup) and it flags the instance the moment it detects the source code changes.

Fifth line from the bottom of the log:
```test
21-06-03 18:27:41 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.evaluations.base] System detect unauthorized source code modifications. (more-info: https://www.home-assistant.io/more-info/unsupported/source_mods)
```

title: brotli compression is not supported but claims it is
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

Using an addon in panel mode (using ingress proxy). When accessing the addon directly on a dedicated port, everything works fine, and responses are compressed to the browser using br.

When the same pages are accessed through HA frontend, using the panel side icon, it comes back with a 0 byte html page, but the addon returned a full 6k page using br compression as the request shows here:

Request as received by addon:
GET / HTTP/1.1
Host: ha.example.com:8123
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Ubuntu; Linux x86_64; rv:88.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/88.0
Accept: text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.7,ja;q=0.3
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Referer: https://ha.example.com:8123/1261b850_tasmobackup
Upgrade-Insecure-Requests: 1
DNT: 1
Connection: keep-alive
Cookie: ingress_session=xxx
X-Ingress-Path: /api/hassio_ingress/4BekXx47JwIwT6SX9_MHqoFAMXZhC0DH1G9cS5B3-QM
X-Forwarded-For: 192.168.10.63, 172.30.32.1
X-Forwarded-Host: ha.example.com:8123
X-Forwarded-Proto: https

Response as sent by the addon:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx
Date: Fri, 28 May 2021 07:35:18 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Connection: keep-alive
Content-Encoding: br
Vary: Accept-Encoding

and the response with brotli disabled produces and works fine in HA:
HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Server: nginx
Date: Fri, 28 May 2021 08:08:14 GMT
Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Connection: keep-alive
Vary: Accept-Encoding
Content-Encoding: gzip

It seems to me that HA is intercepting the response and doing something with it, but is unable to parse the br content-encoding that was requested. I get a 0 byte response in the browser when using br encoded pages in addons, but have no issues if br is not used.


### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

2021-4-3

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant Supervised

### Which operating system are you running on?

Debian

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

10

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

2021-5-5

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. install an addon that can use brotli compression
2. install the addon to the side panel
3. access the addon from the side panel
...


### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
21-05-28 07:35:13 ERROR (MainThread) [supervisor.api.ingress] Stream error with http://172.30.33.4:80/: 400, message='Can not decode content-encoding: br'
21-05-28 07:35:17 ERROR (MainThread) [supervisor.api.ingress] Stream error with http://172.30.33.4:80/: 400, message='Can not decode content-encoding: br'
21-05-28 07:35:18 ERROR (MainThread) [supervisor.api.ingress] Stream error with http://172.30.33.4:80/: 400, message='Can not decode content-encoding: br'
```


### Additional information

_No response_

title: mqtt addon logins password cannot be configured with passwords from secrets.yaml
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

I cannot configure MQTT addon logins with passwords fetched from HA's secrets.yaml file

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.04.3

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Home Assistant OS 5.13

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.5.4

### Steps to reproduce the issue

```yaml
logins:
  - username: mqtt
    password: !secret mqtt_password
customize:
  active: false
  folder: mosquitto
certfile: fullchain.pem
keyfile: privkey.pem
require_certificate: false
anonymous: false
```

However, the config editor in the Add-on GUI in Supervisor shows 'Invalid YAML' message and doesn't allow saving the config.

I've originally reported this issue in the [addons repo](https://github.com/home-assistant/addons/issues/2015) but [according to @frenck](https://github.com/home-assistant/addons/issues/2015#issuecomment-844270855), this should be instead reported here.

### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
Nope, this is blocked on the UI level.

title: Addon schema parser - limited recursion.
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

Options schema for addons is limited to a recursion level of 2 seemingly as a result of this section utilising voluptuous:

[supervisor/addons/validate.py](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/2021.04.3/supervisor/addons/validate.py#L283-L299)
```python
        vol.Optional(ATTR_SCHEMA, default={}): vol.Any(
            vol.Schema(
                {
                    str: vol.Any(
                        SCHEMA_ELEMENT,
                        [
                            vol.Any(
                                SCHEMA_ELEMENT,
                                {str: vol.Any(SCHEMA_ELEMENT, [SCHEMA_ELEMENT])},
                            )
                        ],
                        vol.Schema({str: vol.Any(SCHEMA_ELEMENT, [SCHEMA_ELEMENT])}),
                    )
                }
            ),
            False,
        ),
```

This appears to be overcome when utilising voluptuous' Self feature for recursion as exampled in their docs. 

```python
        vol.Optional(ATTR_SCHEMA, default={}): vol.Any(
            vol.Schema(
                {
                    str: vol.Any(
                        SCHEMA_ELEMENT,
                        vol.Schema({str: vol.Any(SCHEMA_ELEMENT, [SCHEMA_ELEMENT], vol.Self)}),
                        [vol.Any(SCHEMA_ELEMENT, vol.Self)}],
                    )
                }
            ),
            False,
        ),
```

Unfortunately whilst that solves that issue, but it then causes issue with [supervisor/addons/options.py](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/2021.04.3/supervisor/addons/options.py#L298)


### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.04.3

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

5.13

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.5.2

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Configure any addon config.json to have >2 levels of nesting, e.g
```json
{
   "name": "Cloudflare Tunnel",
   "version": "dev",
   "slug": "cloudflare-tunnel",
   "description": "Cloudflare tunnel add-on",
   "url": "<snip>",
   "init": false,
   "arch": [
      "aarch64",
      "amd64",
      "armhf",
      "armv7",
      "i386"
   ],
   "options": {
      "tunnels": [],
      "options": {
         "no-autoupdate": true
      }
   },
   "schema": {
      "tunnels": [
         {
            "enabled": "bool",
            "credentials": {
               "AccountTag": "str",
               "TunnelSecret": "str",
               "TunnelID": "str",
               "TunnelName": "str"
            },
            "ingress":[
           {
                 "hostname": "str?",
                 "service": "str?",
                 "path": "str?"
           }
        ],
            "options": {
               "loglevel": "list(trace|debug|info|warn|error|fatal|panic)?",
               "transport-loglevel": "list(trace|debug|info|warn|error|fatal|panic)?",
               "no-autoupdate": "bool?",
               "no-tls-verify": "bool?"
            }
         }
      ],
      "options": {
         "loglevel": "list(trace|debug|info|warn|error|fatal|panic)?",
         "transport-loglevel": "list(trace|debug|info|warn|error|fatal|panic)?",
         "no-autoupdate": "bool?",
         "no-tls-verify": "bool?"
      }
   }
}
```
2. reload from addon store
3. check supervisor logs



### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
Logs (without updating supervisor/addons/validate.py):

21-05-12 00:58:43 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.store.data] Can't read /data/addons/local/cloudflare-tunnel/config.json: expected string or buffer @ data['schema']['tunnels'][0]['ingress'][0]. Got {'hostname': 'str?', 'service': 'str?', 'path': 'str?'}
expected string or buffer for dictionary value @ data['schema']['tunnels'][0]['credentials']. Got {'AccountTag': 'str', 'TunnelSecret': 'str', 'TunnelID': 'str', 'TunnelName': 'str'}

Logs (with updating supervisor/addons/validate.py):

title: PR 2789 does not allow: "People can run what ever they want"
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

This is somewhere between a bug and a feature request. The "bug" is a recent PR does more than merely warn a user and the "feature request" is to workaround the PR by allowing for slightly more functionality.

---

For at least two months now, I have been making a small change to Supervisor's source code in order to reduce the number of connectivity and version checks. It amounts to nothing more than altering the value of two integers in `tasks.py`.

This value was changed to 7200
```
line 50: RUN_CHECK_CONNECTIVITY = 30
```
and this value was changed to 86400
```
line 456: if value >= 600
```

That was sufficient to perform connectivity checks every few hours and a version check once a day.


I was unaware of [this PR](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/pull/2789) whose goal is:

> This is not to provent code modification, it's just to show that it lost the supported state and people are on his own if they run into issue which not should be sended to sentry. This just prevent reports from modified installation.
> 
> **People can run what ever they want**, it should just not show as supported.

I wish to report that it does _more_ than just benignly warn the user and people cannot "run whatever they want".


I run two instances and both use Home Assistant Supervised on Debian 10. They run a slightly modified Supervisor (as described above) and so both reported they were unsupported and unhealthy. 

On the generic Intel machine, I was allowed to open any of the installed Add-Ons. However, on the RPI3 it prevented me from opening any of the three installed Add-ons (File Editor, Portainer, Samba). The response was "401: Unauthorized". I don't know why the two (otherwise similar) systems differed but they did and the RPI3 version is where I first discovered it was unhealthy due to "source_mods".

On both machines, one could no longer install Add-Ons: 

> Failed to install add-on
> AddonManager.install' blocked from execution, system is not healthy

That's not unexpected, given that the system is now considered unsupported and _unhealthy_, but doesn't comply with the PR's claim "**People can run what ever they want**, it should just not show as supported"

I thought fixing the problem would be as easy as replacing the Supervisor image with a fresh copy but there's no `ha` command to do that (neither `repair` or `update` succeeded). Rather than turn to docker to replace Supervisor's image, I simply reversed the source-code changes I had made, restarted Supervisor, and the system reverted to being healthy and supported.

I suspect the PR was intended to protect users from malicious changes to Supervisor's source code. However, if someone is being truly malicious, they will also _disable this self-check_ thereby rendering this PR moot. As a consequence, only users making benign changes to the code are adversely affected by the PR. 


Ideally, I'd like the self-check to be removed, but I realize that's highly unlikely to happen. Therefore I would appreciate it if the user can be granted control over the frequency of the connectivity/version checks. The current frequency makes my two systems one of the most "chatty" clients on my local network.

---
#### NOTE

Originally I used Home Assistant OS on an RPI3 but its operating system has a hard-coded connectivity check every 5 minutes _in addition to_ the 10-minute connectivity check performed by Supervisor. The check performed by the operating system cannot be throttled so I switched to Home Assistant Supervised on Debian (because Debian does not perform a connectivity check by default). However, now even that avenue has been blocked (because Supervisor's source-code mods are flagged) so I'm left with no functional means of throttling connectivity/version checks (other than switching to Container or Core which seems like a high-maintenance way of acquiring the trivial ability to throttle the checks).


### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.04.3

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant Supervised

### Which operating system are you running on?

Debian

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

2021.5.1

### Steps to reproduce the issue

Simply make a small benign change to `tasks.py` and that's sufficient to prevent installing Add-ons and potentially, as I experienced with an RPI3, even opening existing, installed Add-ons.

### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
Logger: homeassistant.components.hassio
Source: components/hassio/websocket_api.py:109
Integration: Home Assistant Supervisor (documentation, issues)
First occurred: 09:25:01 (2 occurrences)
Last logged: 09:38:50

Failed to to call /addons/core_configurator/install - 'AddonManager.install' blocked from execution, system is not healthy
```


### Additional information

_No response_

title: Healthcheck? error: `stream copy error: reading from a closed fifo`
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

During Supervisor health check (I assume) there's an error regarding custom add-on BUT causing other add-ons (and system?) instability, like crashing/restarting InfluxDB.
I don't remember seeing any influxdb errors previously, so it could be introduced in one of last supervisor updates.

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.04.0

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant Supervised

Debian

title: Supervisor Host card won't update new disk size
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

After getting a warning that my HA was almost out of space, I shutdown the VM, resized the disk from 20GB to 32GB and powered on the VM again. Checking the supervisor -> system -> HOST card, the progress bar was still showing 90% disk usage. And when hovering over the 90% indicator, it still says "17.1/19GB".

However, when I login to the HA VM, fdisk tells me /dev/sda is now 32GB and df -h shows  /dev/sda8 31GB with 17GB usage. So it seems only the card is not updated.

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.04.0

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

5.13

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.4.3

### Steps to reproduce the issue

title: Addon apparmor security point only applied after install
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

According to the section on [AppArmor](https://developers.home-assistant.io/docs/add-ons/presentation#apparmor) in the addon development docs, making a custom AppArmor profile for your addon is worth an extra point in your security score. And it is but its only applied after install. Which seems odd since if your goal was to convince users your add-on is safe you'd ideally want to do that before install, not after.

In my opinion the security score of the addon should be increased prior to install if the addon has an `apparmor.txt` file to be installed along with it.

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.04.1

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

Home Assistant Operating System

5.13

core-2021.4.5

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Go to the add-on store and click on the Dnsmasq add-on
2. Notice it has a 5 for security score
3. Install it, notice it now shows a 6

I fixed the bug and here is my fixed network.py:
```py
"""Info control for host."""
from __future__ import annotations

import asyncio
from ipaddress import IPv4Address, IPv4Interface, IPv6Address, IPv6Interface
import logging
from typing import List, Optional, Union

import attr

from ..const import ATTR_HOST_INTERNET
from ..coresys import CoreSys, CoreSysAttributes
from ..dbus.const import (
    DBUS_NAME_NM_CONNECTION_ACTIVE_CHANGED,
    ConnectionStateType,
    DeviceType,
    InterfaceMethod as NMInterfaceMethod,
    WirelessMethodType,
)
from ..dbus.network.accesspoint import NetworkWirelessAP
from ..dbus.network.connection import NetworkConnection
from ..dbus.network.interface import NetworkInterface
from ..dbus.payloads.generate import interface_update_payload
from ..exceptions import (
    DBusError,
    DBusNotConnectedError,
    DBusProgramError,
    HostNetworkError,
    HostNetworkNotFound,
    HostNotSupportedError,
)
from .const import AuthMethod, InterfaceMethod, InterfaceType, WifiMode

_LOGGER: logging.Logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)


class NetworkManager(CoreSysAttributes):
    """Handle local network setup."""

    def __init__(self, coresys: CoreSys):
        """Initialize system center handling."""
        self.coresys: CoreSys = coresys
        self._connectivity: Optional[bool] = None

    @property
    def connectivity(self) -> Optional[bool]:
        """Return true current connectivity state."""
        return self._connectivity

    @connectivity.setter
    def connectivity(self, state: bool) -> None:
        """Set host connectivity state."""
        if self._connectivity == state:
            return
        self._connectivity = state
        self.sys_homeassistant.websocket.supervisor_update_event(
            "network", {ATTR_HOST_INTERNET: state}
        )

    @property
    def interfaces(self) -> List[Interface]:
        """Return a dictionary of active interfaces."""
        interfaces: List[Interface] = []
        for inet in self.sys_dbus.network.interfaces.values():
            interfaces.append(Interface.from_dbus_interface(inet))

        return interfaces

    @property
    def dns_servers(self) -> List[str]:
        """Return a list of local DNS servers."""
        # Read all local dns servers
        servers: List[str] = []
        for config in self.sys_dbus.network.dns.configuration:
            if config.vpn or not config.nameservers:
                continue
            servers.extend(config.nameservers)

        return list(dict.fromkeys(servers))

    async def check_connectivity(self):
        """Check the internet connection.

        ConnectionState 4 == FULL (has internet)
        https://developer.gnome.org/NetworkManager/stable/nm-dbus-types.html#NMConnectivityState
        """
        if not self.sys_dbus.network.connectivity_enabled:
            return

        # Check connectivity
        try:
            state = await self.sys_dbus.network.check_connectivity()
            self.connectivity = state[0] == 4
        except DBusError as err:
            _LOGGER.warning("Can't update connectivity information: %s", err)
            self.connectivity = False

    def get(self, inet_name: str) -> Interface:
        """Return interface from interface name."""
        if inet_name not in self.sys_dbus.network.interfaces:
            raise HostNetworkNotFound()

        return Interface.from_dbus_interface(
            self.sys_dbus.network.interfaces[inet_name]
        )

    async def update(self):
        """Update properties over dbus."""
        _LOGGER.info("Updating local network information")
        try:
            await self.sys_dbus.network.update()
        except DBusError:
            _LOGGER.warning("Can't update network information!")
        except DBusNotConnectedError as err:
            _LOGGER.error("No network D-Bus connection available")
            raise HostNotSupportedError() from err

        await self.check_connectivity()

    async def apply_changes(self, interface: Interface) -> None:
        """Apply Interface changes to host."""
        inet = self.sys_dbus.network.interfaces.get(interface.name)

        # Update exist configuration
        if (
            inet
            and inet.settings
            and inet.settings.connection.interface_name == interface.name
            and interface.enabled
        ):
            settings = interface_update_payload(
                interface,
                name=inet.settings.connection.id,
                uuid=inet.settings.connection.uuid,
            )

            try:
                await inet.settings.update(settings)
                await self.sys_dbus.network.activate_connection(
                    inet.settings.object_path, inet.object_path
                )
            except DBusError as err:
                _LOGGER.error("Can't update config on %s: %s", interface.name, err)
                raise HostNetworkError() from err

        # Create new configuration and activate interface
        elif inet and interface.enabled:
            settings = interface_update_payload(interface)

            try:
                await self.sys_dbus.network.add_and_activate_connection(
                    settings, inet.object_path
                )
            except DBusError as err:
                _LOGGER.error(
                    "Can't create config and activate %s: %s", interface.name, err
                )
                raise HostNetworkError() from err

        # Remove config from interface
        elif inet and inet.settings and not interface.enabled:
            try:
                await inet.settings.delete()
            except DBusError as err:
                _LOGGER.error("Can't disable interface %s: %s", interface.name, err)
                raise HostNetworkError() from err

        # Create new interface (like vlan)
        elif not inet:
            settings = interface_update_payload(interface)

            try:
                await self.sys_dbus.network.settings.add_connection(settings)
            except DBusError as err:
                _LOGGER.error("Can't create new interface: %s", err)
                raise HostNetworkError() from err
        else:
            _LOGGER.warning("Requested Network interface update is not possible")
            raise HostNetworkError()

        await self.sys_dbus.network.dbus.wait_signal(
            DBUS_NAME_NM_CONNECTION_ACTIVE_CHANGED
        )
        await self.update()

    async def scan_wifi(self, interface: Interface) -> List[AccessPoint]:
        """Scan on Interface for AccessPoint."""
        inet = self.sys_dbus.network.interfaces.get(interface.name)

        if inet.type != DeviceType.WIRELESS:
            _LOGGER.error("Can only scan with wireless card - %s", interface.name)
            raise HostNotSupportedError()

        # Request Scan
        try:
            await inet.wireless.request_scan()
        except DBusProgramError as err:
            _LOGGER.debug("Can't request a new scan: %s", err)
        except DBusError as err:
            raise HostNetworkError() from err
        else:
            await asyncio.sleep(5)

        # Process AP
        accesspoints: List[AccessPoint] = []
        for ap_object in (await inet.wireless.get_all_accesspoints())[0]:
            accesspoint = NetworkWirelessAP(ap_object)

            try:
                await accesspoint.connect()
            except DBusError as err:
                _LOGGER.warning("Can't process an AP: %s", err)
                continue
            else:
                accesspoints.append(
                    AccessPoint(
                        WifiMode[WirelessMethodType(accesspoint.mode).name],
                        accesspoint.ssid,
                        accesspoint.mac,
                        accesspoint.frequency,
                        accesspoint.strength,
                    )
                )

        return accesspoints


@attr.s(slots=True)
class AccessPoint:
    """Represent a wifi configuration."""

    mode: WifiMode = attr.ib()
    ssid: str = attr.ib()
    mac: str = attr.ib()
    frequency: int = attr.ib()
    signal: int = attr.ib()


@attr.s(slots=True)
class IpConfig:
    """Represent a IP configuration."""

    method: InterfaceMethod = attr.ib()
    address: List[Union[IPv4Interface, IPv6Interface]] = attr.ib()
    gateway: Optional[Union[IPv4Address, IPv6Address]] = attr.ib()
    nameservers: List[Union[IPv4Address, IPv6Address]] = attr.ib()


@attr.s(slots=True)
class WifiConfig:
    """Represent a wifi configuration."""

    mode: WifiMode = attr.ib()
    ssid: str = attr.ib()
    auth: AuthMethod = attr.ib()
    psk: Optional[str] = attr.ib()
    signal: Optional[int] = attr.ib()


@attr.s(slots=True)
class VlanConfig:
    """Represent a vlan configuration."""

    id: int = attr.ib()
    interface: str = attr.ib()


@attr.s(slots=True)
class Interface:
    """Represent a host network interface."""

    name: str = attr.ib()
    enabled: bool = attr.ib()
    connected: bool = attr.ib()
    primary: bool = attr.ib()
    type: InterfaceType = attr.ib()
    ipv4: Optional[IpConfig] = attr.ib()
    ipv6: Optional[IpConfig] = attr.ib()
    wifi: Optional[WifiConfig] = attr.ib()
    vlan: Optional[VlanConfig] = attr.ib()

    @staticmethod
    def from_dbus_interface(inet: NetworkInterface) -> Interface:
        """Concert a dbus interface into normal Interface."""
        return Interface(
            inet.name,
            inet.settings is not None,
            Interface._map_nm_connected(inet.connection),
            inet.primary,
            Interface._map_nm_type(inet.type),
            IpConfig(
                Interface._map_nm_method(inet.settings.ipv4.method),
                inet.connection.ipv4.address,
                inet.connection.ipv4.gateway,
                inet.connection.ipv4.nameservers,
            )
            if inet.connection and inet.connection.ipv4
            else IpConfig(InterfaceMethod.DISABLED, [], None, []),
            IpConfig(
                Interface._map_nm_method(inet.settings.ipv6.method),
                inet.connection.ipv6.address,
                inet.connection.ipv6.gateway,
                inet.connection.ipv6.nameservers,
            )
            if inet.connection and inet.connection.ipv6
            else IpConfig(InterfaceMethod.DISABLED, [], None, []),
            Interface._map_nm_wifi(inet),
            Interface._map_nm_vlan(inet),
        )

    @staticmethod
    def _map_nm_method(method: str) -> InterfaceMethod:
        """Map IP interface method."""
        mapping = {
            NMInterfaceMethod.AUTO: InterfaceMethod.AUTO,
            NMInterfaceMethod.DISABLED: InterfaceMethod.DISABLED,
            NMInterfaceMethod.MANUAL: InterfaceMethod.STATIC,
        }

        return mapping.get(method, InterfaceMethod.DISABLED)

    @staticmethod
    def _map_nm_connected(connection: Optional[NetworkConnection]) -> bool:
        """Map connectivity state."""
        if not connection:
            return False

        return connection.state in (
            ConnectionStateType.ACTIVATED,
            ConnectionStateType.ACTIVATING,
        )

    @staticmethod
    def _map_nm_type(device_type: int) -> InterfaceType:
        mapping = {
            DeviceType.ETHERNET: InterfaceType.ETHERNET,
            DeviceType.WIRELESS: InterfaceType.WIRELESS,
            DeviceType.VLAN: InterfaceType.VLAN,
        }
        return mapping[device_type]

    @staticmethod
    def _map_nm_wifi(inet: NetworkInterface) -> Optional[WifiConfig]:
        """Create mapping to nm wifi property."""
        if inet.type != DeviceType.WIRELESS or not inet.settings:
            return None

        # Authentication
        auth = None
        if not inet.settings.wireless_security:
            auth = AuthMethod.OPEN
        elif inet.settings.wireless_security.key_mgmt == "none":
                auth = AuthMethod.WEP
        elif inet.settings.wireless_security.key_mgmt == "wpa-psk":
                auth = AuthMethod.WPA_PSK

        # WifiMode
        mode = WifiMode.INFRASTRUCTURE
        if inet.settings.wireless.mode:
            mode = WifiMode(inet.settings.wireless.mode)

        # Signal
        if inet.wireless:
            signal = inet.wireless.active.strength
        else:
            signal = None

        if not inet.settings.wireless_security:
            passwd = None
        else:
            passwd = inet.settings.wireless_security.psk

        return WifiConfig(
            mode,
            inet.settings.wireless.ssid,
            auth,
            passwd,
            signal,
        )

    @staticmethod
    def _map_nm_vlan(inet: NetworkInterface) -> Optional[WifiConfig]:
        """Create mapping to nm vlan property."""
        if inet.type != DeviceType.VLAN or not inet.settings:
            return None

        return VlanConfig(inet.settings.vlan.id, inet.settings.vlan.parent)
```

### Describe the issue you are experiencing

Hello, I've been trying to get rid of running unsupported error message for a bit now. I asked in the home assistant community but no one seems to have an answer for it. 
I installed home assistant supervised following the guidelines in debian 10. 
I added the parts of code into the proper conf file to make network-manager manager but it doesn't seems to get rid of the problem.

This the code I put into 
/etc/NetworkManager/NetworkManager.conf:

[main]
dns=default
plugins=keyfile
autoconnect-retries-default=0
rc-manager=file

[keyfile]
unmanaged-devices=type:bridge;type:tun;type:veth

[logging]
backend=journal

and into 
/etc/NetworkManager/system-connections/default:

[connection]
id=Supervisor default
uuid=b653440a-544a-4e4f-aef5-6c443171c4f8
type=802-3-ethernet
llmnr=2
mdns=2

[ipv4]
method=auto

[ipv6]
addr-gen-mode=stable-privacy
method=auto

and into
/etc/network/interfaces:

source /etc/network/interfaces.d/*

auto lo
iface lo inet loopback

supervisor-2021.03.6

Debian

core-2021.3.4

1. Just starting home assistant you get it as not supported.
2.
3.
...

```


I connected my raspberry pi4 with wifi using iwd, following some instructions to connect it to wifi but it wasn't working and ended up disabling and reenabling network-manager.

I tried restarting my raspberry with and without the ethernet cable connected but I get same result.

I configured wpa_supplicant at some point as well.

Other than that I can't think of anything else that may have affected the installation to not be supported.

Thanks in advance,
Francisco

title: All messages logged as error. No filtering
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

```hassio_supervisor``` currently logs all output as errors (level 3), also for information level messages (marked "INFO" in the text).

Maybe addressing this by assigning a proper log level to messages, will also make it possible to filter ```hassio_supervisor``` output based on the Logger settings in ```configuration.yaml```, as described in the [HA Logger documentation](https://www.home-assistant.io/integrations/logger).

Because currently all messages are flagged as errors, it is not possible to filter out unwanted messages based on level in downstream apps (e.g. rsyslog).



### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.03.4

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant Supervised

### Which operating system are you running on?

Debian

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.2.3

### Steps to reproduce the issue

Just let Home Assistant run for a while to allow it to generate some logs, the problem will show itself. No special action needed.

### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

Easiest way to see this is selecting ```hassio_supervisor``` error-level messages from journalctl. 

```
journalctl CONTAINER_NAME=hassio_supervisor -p err
...
Mar 09 15:38:21 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:38:21 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.host.info] Updating local host information
Mar 09 15:38:21 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:38:21 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.host.services] Updating service information
Mar 09 15:38:22 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:38:22 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.host.network] Updating local network information
Mar 09 15:38:23 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:38:23 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.host.sound] Updating PulseAudio information
Mar 09 15:38:23 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:38:23 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.host] Host information reload completed
Mar 09 15:44:20 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:44:20 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.check] Starting system checks with state CoreState.RUNNING
Mar 09 15:44:20 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:44:20 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.checks.base] Run check for IssueType.SECURITY/ContextType.CORE
Mar 09 15:44:20 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:44:20 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.checks.base] Run check for IssueType.FREE_SPACE/ContextType.SYSTEM
Mar 09 15:44:20 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:44:20 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.checks.base] Run check for IssueType.PWNED/ContextType.ADDON
Mar 09 15:44:20 RPiHome 5d455224b8b3[584]: 21-03-09 14:44:20 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.resolution.check] System checks complete
...
```

And to confirm, see the PRIORITY level in the message detail.
For the first record above (note ```PRIORITY=3```):

```
journalctl CONTAINER_NAME=hassio_supervisor --since "2021-03-09 15:38:20" --until "2021-03-09 15:38:30" -o verbose
-- Logs begin at Mon 2021-03-08 22:43:29 CET, end at Fri 2021-03-12 21:46:29 CET. --
Tue 2021-03-09 15:38:21.685952 CET [s=e0ae8b76d4cd495caeca4d33ba3702ea;i=20d;b=285f795042f04f8588bbdd5ce295afd7;m=e2cf266ea;t=5bd1b80878f4f;x=339dc0ca30996b1e]
    _BOOT_ID=285f795042f04f8588bbdd5ce295afd7
    _MACHINE_ID=be042b18af4b495ca4957bfef9e53efd
    _HOSTNAME=RPiHome
    _UID=0
    _GID=0
    _SYSTEMD_SLICE=system.slice
    _TRANSPORT=journal
    _CAP_EFFECTIVE=1ffffffffff
    PRIORITY=3
    _PID=584
    _COMM=dockerd
    _EXE=/usr/bin/dockerd
    _CMDLINE=/usr/bin/dockerd -H fd:// --containerd=/run/containerd/containerd.sock
    _SYSTEMD_CGROUP=/system.slice/docker.service
    _SYSTEMD_UNIT=docker.service
    _SYSTEMD_INVOCATION_ID=02eb6c5d4ad24576bd16a7252e7c8802
    CONTAINER_NAME=hassio_supervisor
    CONTAINER_TAG=5d455224b8b3
    IMAGE_NAME=homeassistant/armv7-hassio-supervisor
    SYSLOG_IDENTIFIER=5d455224b8b3
    CONTAINER_ID=5d455224b8b3
    CONTAINER_ID_FULL=5d455224b8b324e215a4f570202504bd51f0dd2f688bb92b28f52906a7b7a4b4
    MESSAGE=[99B blob data]
    _SOURCE_REALTIME_TIMESTAMP=1615300701685952

```

Setting a default logger value in ```configuration.yaml``` has no effect on what ```hassio_supervisor``` messages are logged.
Maybe there is a specific component that can be used to filter Supervisor messages? (although the "default" setting should cover everything that is not specifically defined).

```
logger:
  default: critical
  logs:
    homeassistant.core: fatal
```

May be partly covered by [Log messages cleanup #2129](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/pull/2129)?

title: Pwned check returns after dismissal
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

Since the launch of the new pwned check (#2614), I've been receiving constant alerts that one of my addons, [Network UPS Tools](https://github.com/hassio-addons/addon-nut), has a compromised password.

While the alert is correct, this is known in my local setup, and I have no option for resolution as my NUT server (Synology) does not allow customization of the user and password.

Receiving a warning on first run is okay after updating a configuration, but this is happening every few hours. As there is nothing I can do to resolve the password issue on my end, I have a persistent security alert in my notifications.

This appears to be frustrating other users, as I've seen some recent posts about it: https://www.reddit.com/r/homeassistant/comments/lx5wnr/pwned/

I'm all for increased security, but we should also have some manual controls around this, or at the very least, less noisy.

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.03.4

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Home Assistant OS 5.12

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.3.1

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Configure an add-on with a compromised password. For example, my NUT configuration:

```
users: []
devices: []
mode: netclient
shutdown_host: true
remote_ups_name: ups
remote_ups_host: <removed>
remote_ups_user: monuser
remote_ups_password: secret
```

2. Receive a pwned warning every few hours.

### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
# Put your logs below this line

title: Adding a custom repository removes existing custom repositories
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

I recently added a custom repository, I had 4 existing which were added with various previous versions of core/supervisor. When added the system removed the existing repositories. I see the remove action noted in the logs.

Adding back a previous repository it again removes existing custom repositories. Seems at the moment you can only have 1 custom repository.

supervisor-2021.03.3
core-2021.3.0

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.03.3

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

Home Assistant OS 5.12

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.3.0

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Have existing custom repositories in the store.
2. Add a different custome repository

title: Cannot mount /dev/sda1 inside my own addon with privileged mode enabled
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

I use my own custom modified addon version of MariaDB
(please keep in mind this is not a problem with addon itself)

So i run it with protection mode disabled, and i mount external USB drive
to offload files to it, so microSD card is not wearing much.

I was always updating Supervisor whenever possible, and all was running
smoothly well, until i updated OS to 5.12 (which obviously caused reboot)
and problem started. I tried to fill a report in here:
https://github.com/home-assistant/operating-system/issues/1259
but was informed, that most probably it is not OS, its Supervisor change
that is causing it.

I tried logging into addon console with portainer, and trying to do:

bash-5.0# mount /dev/sda1 /share/usb
mount: permission denied (are you root?)
bash-5.0# whoami
root

What has changed? How can i again mount my USB drive and use it inside my addon?
Also - USB drive is healthy, i tried it on my PC and it mounts RW okay.
file system check also did not find any errors on it.
File system on it is EXT4 if this matters.

Are there any new permissions needed to mount external drive to addon?

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

supervisor-2021.03.3

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant OS

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

5.12

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

core-2021.2.3

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. Create addon with privileged permissions
2. Try to mount /dev/sdXX device
3. mount fails
...


### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

```txt
# Put your logs below this line
Nothing is seend in supervisor while trying to do mount.
```

title: joined beta 2021.03.1 (blank supervisor page)
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

After joining beta channel for supervisor, updating and rebooting, the supervisor UI now renders a blank page.

### What is the used version of the Supervisor?

2021.03.1

### What type of installation are you running?

Home Assistant Supervised

### Which operating system are you running on?

Home Assistant Operating System

### What is the version of your installed operating system?

latest (can't get to supervisor to see)

### What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?

latest (can't get to supervisor to see)

### Steps to reproduce the issue

1. joined my HA environment to the beta channel
2. updated 
3. rebooted host

After reboot; seems everything else is working but I can no longer get to the supervisor UI.  The page is rendered blank
...


### Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?

I can't copy/paste from the UI shell.  I do see this message:

supervisor_event is not supported untill core-2021.2.4. Ignoring WebSocket message

If not easily fixable, is there a way I can remote my ha environment from beta channel through the HA shell? And update back to stable channel?

title: Supervisor when opening Unable to load the panel source: /api/hassio/app/entrypoint.js.
body:
### Describe the issue you are experiencing

When I try to open the supervisor tab I get the following error:

Unable to load the panel source: /api/hassio/app/entrypoint.js.

I have tried and checked the following things so far:

- Homassisnt observer says all is ok :

Home Assistant observer
Supervisor:
Connected

- With portainer I recreated the supervisor with pulling the latest image without succes
- Checked the container logs which showed nothing that indicates the problem to me/

2021.03.0

Home Assistant Supervised

Other (e.g., Raspbian/Raspberry Pi OS/Fedora)

After upgrade to 5.12 wlan0 config lost and UI does not allow configure DHCP or static IP on wlan0 
- always Disabled both IPv4 & IPv6.

While eth0 connected - not possible to configure wlan0 IP (DHCP ot static).
On eth0 disconnected - have no idea, as no connectivity.

title: No access to ttyS0 on raspberry pi for addons with "uart" flag
body:
**Describe the issue you are experiencing**

My addon working with raspberry HW serial port started experiencing "Operation not permitted" issue while accessing /dev/ttyS0 port on Raspberry. The addon has `"uart": true` in its JSON declaration.


**What is the used version of the Supervisor?**

supervisor-2021.02.11

**What type of installation are you running?**

Home Assistant OS

**Which operating system are you running on?**

Home Assistant Operating System

**What is the version of your installed operating system?**

5.11

**What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?**

core-2021.2.2

**Steps to reproduce the issue**

The easiest to reproduce example is as follows:

1. [enable UART](https://www.raspberrypi.org/documentation/configuration/uart.md) for Raspberry PI with `enable_uart` 
2. run official SSH addon
3. try reading from ttyS0

Results:
```console
~ $ tail /dev/ttyAMA0
~ $ tail /dev/ttyS0
tail: can't open '/dev/ttyS0': Operation not permitted
tail: no files
```


**Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?**

```txt
# Put your logs below this line

```


My investigation led me to #2429 where "auto_uart" was renamed to "uart" and also the `cgroups_rules` function was added. As I can see from supervisor/hardware/policy.py 
```
PolicyGroup.UART: [204, 188, 166, 244],
```
As I can see from https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/admin-guide/devices.txt
ttyS* devices should have '4' and I can see it from inside the addon:
```console
~ $ ls -la /dev/ttyAMA0 /dev/ttyS0
crw-rw----    1 root     audio     204,  64 Feb 24 15:49 /dev/ttyAMA0
crw-rw----    1 root     audio       4,  64 Feb  3 00:18 /dev/ttyS0
```

title: Unable to mount USB device after supervisor update
body:
Yesterday my HA updated the Supervisor to *'supervisor-2021.02.11'*.  
After a reboot today I **can't** mount my USB storage anymore:  

  `mount: mounting /dev/sda1 on /share/usb failed: Permission denied`  

Before yesterday, it worked as expected.  
  
I have an EXT4 formatted USB thumb drive connected to my RPi 2.  
I use a slightly modified version of the MariaDB addon, to host the database on the thumb drive and prevent issues with my SD-Card. Until yesterday, this worked like a charm (even though I had to disable the 'Protection mode')!
  
I don't think using a thumb drive as an extra storage is a security threat anyway, so blocking it in protection mode is overprotecting the system imho.

Please enable access to my usb drive (/dev/sda*) again.  
I can live with disabling 'Protection Mode' or is there an other way of mounting it, that I'm not thinking of or am aware of?

title: Unable to update to 2021.02.9
body:
**Describe the issue you are experiencing**

Can't update supervisor to 2021.02.9 running on docker.

title: Add-on configuration is broken for dynamic config properties
body:
**Describe the issue you are experiencing**

After the recent schema change it is impossible to use dynamic setting keys with Home Assistant add-ons. You can only hardcode the available keys. An example of a configuration that is broken in the most recent versions of the Supervisor:

```yaml
entities:
  behaviors:
    ble_SOME_ID_OF_THE_USER:
      debounce:
        wait: 0.75
        maxWait: 2
```

This issue should be considered aside from the fact that the nesting doesn't work (#2560).

(I know that this is tip-toeing the line between bug and feature request - I've filed it as a bug report since it was working before with `schema: false`.)

**What is the used version of the Supervisor?**

supervisor-2021.02.6

**What type of installation are you running?**

Home Assistant Supervised

**Which operating system are you running on?**

Debian

**What is the version of your installed operating system?**

9.13

**What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?**

core-2021.2.1

**Steps to reproduce the issue**

1. Have an add-on that needs dynamic config properties ([example](https://github.com/mKeRix/hassio-repo/blob/master/room_assistant/config.json)).
2. Try to write a schema that works with that on the latest Supervisor version. :)


**Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?**

_No response_

This issue is aftermath of #2540, more info for this specific add-on can be found at mKeRix/room-assistant#501. This problem is preventing me from restoring the same functionality that my add-on had before the schema change.

title: Validation does not support deeply nested objects
Validation requires objects/arrays to always exist
body:
**Describe the issue you are experiencing**

An object or an array that is defined in the schema always needs to be present in the options, even if all its properties are optional. This leads to add-on default configs looking like this:

```yaml
global:
  instanceName: changeme
  integrations:
    - bluetoothLowEnergy
cluster:
  autoDiscovery: false
  peerAddresses: []
bluetoothLowEnergy:
  allowlist: []
  denylist: []
bluetoothClassic:
  addresses: []
omronD6t: {}
gridEye: {}
homeAssistant: {}
```

To grant my users the same experience across all platforms I would expect to see something like this work:

```yaml
global:
  instanceName: changeme
  integrations:
    - bluetoothLowEnergy
```

As soon as you remove any of the keys specified in the default above you are met with the following error:

```txt
Failed to save addon configuration, not a valid value for dictionary value @ data['options']
```

You can find the sample schema [here](https://github.com/mKeRix/hassio-repo/blob/master/room_assistant/config.json).

**What is the used version of the Supervisor?**

supervisor-2021.02.6

**What type of installation are you running?**

Home Assistant Supervised

**Which operating system are you running on?**

Debian

**What is the version of your installed operating system?**

9.13

**What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?**

core-2021.2.1

**Steps to reproduce the issue**

1. Add my add-on repo: https://github.com/mKeRix/hassio-repo
2. Install the room-assistant add-on.
3. Try to remove any of the empty object or empty array properties, then save.


**Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?**

_No response_

This issue is aftermath of #2540, more info for this specific add-on can be found at mKeRix/room-assistant#501.

title: Not able to create pipe files in /dev with supervisor-2021.02.6
body:
**Describe the issue you are experiencing**

With the change of device handling in the supervisor update to 2021.02.6 the pigpio addon of mine stopped working.
Now it can't create its pipe devices `/dev/pigerr` and ` /dev/pigpio` from inside the addon.

```txt

2021-02-10 01:01:16 pthFifoThread: fopen /dev/pigpio failed(No such file or directory)
```

Is there a way to allow specific device creation? Or create them beforehand?

**What is the used version of the Supervisor?**

supervisor-2021.02.6

**What type of installation are you running?**

Home Assistant OS

**Which operating system are you running on?**

Home Assistant Operating System

**What is the version of your installed operating system?**

5.11

core-2021.2.2

_No response_

title: Add-ons and integration errors after auto-upgrade to supervisor-2021.02.6
body:
**Describe the issue you are experiencing**

After an auto-upgrade during the night, I did notice that my zigbee devices were slow to answer.
I then did reload and was unable to send any commands to my zigbee devices. I saw also a lot of add-ons and integrations errors in the logs. Did update all the add-ons, reload, update HA to last core version core-2021.2.2 (from core-2021.2.1), reload with no success. Did also try a restore a snapshot with version core-2021.1.5, delete the db, tried a rebuild with no success.
A couple of people like me were stuck. I tried to downgrade to supervisor version 2021.01.8 but was unable to prevent an auto-upgrade to last version.

title: Possible Spelling mistake in addon.py
body:
**Describe the issue you are experiencing**

Line 427 in addon.py might have a spelling mistake. I think envoirement should be environment:

_LOGGER.error("Invalid build envoirement, can't build this add-on!")

I'm not sure how to make a pull request to fix it so I just wanted to let you know 🙂

**What is the used version of the Supervisor?**

supervisor-2021.02.6

**What type of installation are you running?**

Home Assistant OS

**Which operating system are you running on?**

Home Assistant Operating System

**What is the version of your installed operating system?**

5.11

**What version of Home Assistant Core is installed?**

core-2021.2.2

**Steps to reproduce the issue**

1. Tried to use an unsupported build environment for an Add On
2. Received the misspelled error message in the supervisor log

**Anything in the Supervisor logs that might be useful for us?**

```txt
# Put your logs below this line
21-02-09 21:25:27 ERROR (SyncWorker_0) [supervisor.docker.addon] Invalid build envoirement, can't build this add-on!
```


Thanks for all of the work you do for this amazing software!
