title: Wrong tmpfs location after #2499 merged
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

<!-- Provide as many details as possible. -->

/tmp and /tmpfs is mixed up in #2499 

Documentation says `Is this True, the containers /tmp is using tmpfs, an memory file system.`

Though /tmp is on the SD card, and we have /tmpfs (this is from `docker exec ... /bin/bash` from a tmpfs enabled add-on):

```text
bash-5.0# df -h /tmp /tmpfs /dev/shm
Filesystem                Size      Used Available Use% Mounted on
overlay                  28.0G      6.7G     19.9G  25% /
tmpfs                   461.9M     28.7M    433.2M   6% /tmpfs
tmpfs                   461.9M         0    461.9M   0% /dev/shm

```

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. enable tmpfs in add-on's config.json
2. build & install add-on
3. check with df

### Enviroment details

- **Supervisor version:**: supervisor-2021.02.6
- **Home Assistant version**: core-2021.2.2

title: Home assistant fails to fully start resulting in snapshot not working and Zwave not working
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

I upgraded this morning to Home assistant 2021.2.1. Prior to this my installation was working really well (aside from some IKEA tradfri issues). I noticed zwave components weren't added to the UI, and it turns out they were not discovered at all. I found Openzwave was deprecated, so I deactivated it and installed Zwave JS instead. The addon does not indicate any errors as far as I can tell, but it still wont add zwave components to my system. It ends with:

14:57:10.182 CNTRLR   [Node 007] Interview stage completed: Neighbors
14:57:10.182 CNTRLR   [Node 007] Interview completed

 I tried to rewind the installation to my previous version by using the snapshot I have, but it fails to work. I'm not sure if the issue is with Zwave JS, or something else with my system. 

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Startup my system by rebooting my machine (sudo reboot now)
2. Try to create a snapshot or restore from snapshot

I have tried to deactivate all addons except duckdns. 

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

title: Unable to restart supervisor (or core) if core block startup
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

(Disclaimer, it's really unclear to me whether this issue is with core, supervisor, or even the OS. It's possible I have a corrupted database or installation. My gut is saying to start here though.)

After updating to 2021.2.0 last night, my instance booted up, but never finishes loading. That is, the message saying "Home Assistant is starting, not everything will be available until it is finished." at the bottom never goes away.

When trying to restart core via UI or via CLI, I get these errors in Supervisor logs:
```
21-02-04 17:41:25 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.jobs] 'Supervisor.restart' blocked from execution, system is not running - CoreState.STARTUP
21-02-04 17:47:07 ERROR (MainThread) [supervisor.utils] Can't execute restart while a task is in progress
```

When trying to restart supervisor via UI or via CLI, I get the "Unknown error, see supervisor" error message. The Supervisor logs show this:
```
21-02-04 17:48:15 WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.jobs] 'Supervisor.restart' blocked from execution, system is not running - CoreState.STARTUP
```

Not sure if it's related, but in my core logs I see this:
```
2021-02-04 09:38:45 WARNING (Recorder) [homeassistant.components.recorder] Ended unfinished session (id=37 from 2021-02-04 04:47:53)
```



<!-- Provide as many details as possible. -->

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

I can reproduce the errors consistently by:

1. Going to Supervisor -> System
2. Clicking "Restart Supervisor"
3. Refreshing Supervisor logs

Or:

1. Going to Terminal
2. Typing `ha supervisor restart`

title: Failed to start mosquitto, esphome, ssh terminal and many other add-ons
body:
### Describe the issue

Getting error when start addons:

Failed to start addon
400 Client Error for http+docker://localhost/v1.39/containers/d1963d9a28e9a1361d739f8a89e92ed0cc9662a28fffba662c5e5ae950b8e5e7/start: Bad Request ("OCI runtime create failed: container_linux.go:345: starting container process caused "exec: "/dev/init": stat /dev/init: no such file or directory": unknown")

### Steps to reproduce

Just start addon on from Supervisor page

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**: Synology
- **Supervisor version:**: core-2021.1.5, 
Supervisor Version supervisor-2021.02.3
Newest Version supervisor-2021.01.7
- **Home Assistant version**: 2021.1.5

**Please note the shown newest version is less than actual**

title: Supervisor UI will Prompt to Downgrade if Updated via CLI
body:
### Describe the issue

The Supervisor UI will prompt a user to "downgrade" (Update to a lower version) if they are on a version that is *greater than* (and not equal to) the current running version.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/652006/105615539-147b4580-5d97-11eb-9843-cbb3a844a73a.png)

#### Reccomendation

Use *semantic versioning comparison* to check that the target version is newer, instead of not equal to.

SemVer comparison reference question for Python here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11887762/how-do-i-compare-version-numbers-in-python (Apologies, I am a developer, but not a Python dev! 😁 So I know what to fix, but not how to fix it!)

### Steps to reproduce

*Note: These steps are generalized/arbitrary just so you can get the idea.*

1. Update HA Core to "Version 6"
2. Release "Version 7" publicly
3. Ensure the Supervisor does not alert on, or fetch the "Version 7" notice yet
4. Update via the CLI manually (1ha core update --version=7`)
5. Browse to the Supervisor tab after HA Core restarts.

### Enviroment details

- **Operating System:**: Home Assistant OS 5.10 (*Virtual Machine Host: VirtualBox running on Windows 10*)
- **Supervisor version:**: supervisor-2021.01.5

-->

### Describe the issue
Hi,
I have a huge lag when accessing the supervisor or even any supervisor addon through the android app or even chrome when I'm not on the same network as the server.

You can find my forum post here with some screenshots : https://community.home-assistant.io/t/supervisor-slow-loading-when-outside-network/248593/10

It seems like it is caused by /api/hassio/app/frontend_latest/entrypoint.6bc241a4.js that takes a lot of time to load. I made a performance test and it seems like it.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Be on an external network (4G, at work, etc...
2. Access supervisor tab or a supervisor addon (for example adguard or zigbee2mqtt web page)

### Enviroment details

RPI4 4GB RAM (using good power adapter)
128Gb SANDISK usb hard drive (boot on usb)
Debian 10 buster using docker v19.03.14 (followed https://community.home-assistant.io/t/installing-home-assistant-supervised-on-a-raspberry-pi-with-debian-10/247116)
Using duckdns + nginx
Conbee 2 attached
Addons: ADB, adguard home (disabled), duckdns, file editor, home assistant google drive backup, influxdb (disabled), mariadb, mosquitto broker, nginx, node-red (disabled), valetudo mapper, visual studio code, zibee2mqtt edge, deconz (disabled)
Core version: core-2021.1.4
Supervisor version: supervisor-2021.01.5 (chanell stable)
Speedtest server side: 19.5Mbps download, 1Mbps upload
Speedtest client side: 45Mbps download, 2Mbps upload

### Supervisor logs
Not sure what logs I can give since there isn't any errors or such.

### System Information
Not sure if I can use this command since I'm not on HA OS. You can find this info in the environnement details.

body:

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue
Installing an addon that has a version of "v0.1.0", the installation of the add-on fails.
```
21-01-17 11:13:19 ERROR (SyncWorker_9) [supervisor.docker.interface] Can't install berichta/caddy-2-aarch64:0.1.0 -> 404 Client Error for http+docker://localhost/v1.40/images/create?tag=0.1.0&fromImage=berichta%2Fcaddy-2-aarch64: Not Found ("manifest for berichta/caddy-2-aarch64:0.1.0 not found: manifest unknown: manifest unknown").
```

Within the `config.json`, the following version tag failed and caused the above issue:
```
"version": "v0.1.0",
```

After changing the version tag and removing the letter character "v", the installation worked as expected:
```
"version": "0.1.1",
```

title: dev instructions in README don't work
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

Follow the developer instructions in the README and get an error in one of the steps (setting channel=dev).

Ignoring the error and proceeding with the developer instructions will allow you to use your supervisor image and test it, however the logs will report that the system verification failed and the system will fall back to the latest stable version on the next supervisor restart.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Obtain ssh root access to your ha instance on port 22222
2. Run `ha supervisor options --channel=dev` as stated in the README

```
ha > ha supervisor options --channel=dev
Error: unknown flag: --channel
Usage:
  ha core [command]

Aliases:
  core, homeassistant, home-assistant, ha

Examples:

  ha core check
  ha core restart
  ha core update
        ha core update --version 0.97.2

Available Commands:
  check       Validates your Home Assistant Core configuration
  info        Provides information about Home Assistant Core
  logs        View the log output of Home Assistant Core
  options     Allow to set options on Home Assistant Core instance
  rebuild     Rebuild the Home Assistant Core instance
  restart     Restarts the Home Assistant Core
  start       Manually start Home Assistant Core
  stats       Provides system usage stats of Home Assistant Core
  stop        Manually stop Home Assistant Core
  update      Updates the Home Assistant Core

Flags:
  -h, --help   help for core

Global Flags:
      --api-token string   Home Assistant Supervisor API token
      --config string      Optional config file (default is $HOME/.homeassistant.yaml)
      --endpoint string    Endpoint for Home Assistant Supervisor (default is 'supervisor')
      --log-level string   Log level (defaults to Warn)
      --no-progress        Disable the progress spinner
      --raw-json           Output raw JSON from the API

Use "ha core [command] --help" for more information about a command.

FATA[0000] Error while executing rootCmd: unknown flag: --channel
```

title: Supervisor wrongly assumes 401 means "expired access token" when the hassio component meant "invalid credentials"
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

When an addon tries to use http://supervisor/auth with an invalid password, it gets an error `{"result": "error", "message": "Unknown error, see supervisor"}` instead of a 401 response.

The [Home Assistant hassio component](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/ac3a6aaa8cdb005b3c900f9d9671e5a859351060/homeassistant/components/hassio/auth.py#L75) returns 401 if the given credentials are invalid (that's the standard and expected response), but that response is interpreted by [`make_request`](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/homeassistant/api.py#L90-L93) as if the access token had expired, raising a `HomeAssistantApiError` instead of returning the expected 401 response to successfully deny access.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->
1. An addon with `auth_api: true` uses a request with an invalid password like:

        curl -X POST -H "X-Supervisor-Token: ${SUPERVISOR_TOKEN}" http://valid_user:invalid_password@supervisor/auth

2. The [auth endpoint](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/api/auth.py#L66) calls [_process_basic](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/api/auth.py#L36) that forwards credentials to [check_login](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/auth.py#L64).

3. `check_login` [calls](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/auth.py#L87) [_backend_login](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/auth.py#L92) which [makes a request](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/auth.py#L95). The [make_request](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/homeassistant/api.py#L58) function verifies the token and [retrieves the response from home assistant `api/hassio_auth`](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/homeassistant/api.py#L89).

4. [Then](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/homeassistant/api.py#L90-L93), if it gets a 401 response, it assumes the access token has expired. If that happens twice, `make_response` raises a `HomeAssistantApiError`.

And *there is the error*: The [Home Assistant hassio component](https://github.com/home-assistant/core/blob/ac3a6aaa8cdb005b3c900f9d9671e5a859351060/homeassistant/components/hassio/auth.py#L75) also returns 401 if the given credentials are invalid (that's the standard and expected response), but that response is interpreted by [`make_request`](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/blob/bff4af25349c8b3c3de45d993720cd2ab1b92208/supervisor/homeassistant/api.py#L90-L93) as if the access token had expired, raising a `HomeAssistantApiError` instead of returning the 401 response that `_backend_login` expects to successfully deny access.


### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**: Home Assistant OS 5.9
- **Supervisor version:**: 2020.12.7
- **Home Assistant version**: 2020.12.1

### Supervisor logs

<details>
<summary>Supervisor logs</summary>
<!--
- Frontend -> Supervisor -> System
- Or use this command: ha supervisor logs
- Logs are more than just errors, even if you don't think it's important, it is.
-->

```
21-01-07 15:53:39 INFO (MainThread) [__main__] Initializing Supervisor setup
21-01-07 15:53:39 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.bootstrap] Initializing Supervisor Sentry
```

title: Name resolution stopped working
body:
### Describe the issue

For some reason my homeassistant name resolution is no longer working. E.g., it cannot reach alexa.amazon.de, api.tibber.com and other addresses to set up the integrations.
Any idea what could cause this?
In the terminal I can see that in resolv.conf the nameserver is pointing to localhost. If I manually add a known working nameserver then name resolution on the console is working.

resolv.con is pointing to 127.0.0.11 - which is not working for some reason.

I've already tried a reboot which is not changing anything. In fact, the issue occured the first time when I rebooted (to update an integration).
Also checked my local network nameserver settings - and all looks fine.
I've also tried to change the ip address to a static one (because this way I can manually define the nameserver) - but it does not seem to do anything either.

What I can see in the supervisor logs are several errors like this:
21-01-06 10:48:37 ERROR (MainThread) [supervisor.api.ingress] Ingress error: Cannot connect to host 172.30.32.1:62565 ssl:default [Connect call failed ('172.30.32.1', 62565)]

When trying to resolve a name in the terminal (nslookup), I get this:

```
> alexa.amazon.de
Server:         127.0.0.11
Address:        127.0.0.11#53

** server can't find alexa.amazon.de: SERVFAIL
```
If I manually change the server to a known working nameserver, I get this:
```
> server 9.9.9.9
Default server: 9.9.9.9
Address: 9.9.9.9#53
> alexa.amazon.de
Server:         9.9.9.9
Address:        9.9.9.9#53

Non-authoritative answer:
alexa.amazon.de canonical name = layla.amazon.com.
layla.amazon.com        canonical name = tp.799c43337-frontier.amazon.com.
tp.799c43337-frontier.amazon.com        canonical name = d3rsqup3tcxj1a.cloudfront.net.
Name:   d3rsqup3tcxj1a.cloudfront.net
Address: 13.224.185.30
```

### Steps to reproduce

The error occurs no matter what I do.

### Enviroment details

**Operating System:**: 5.9
- **Supervisor version:**: 2020.12.7
- **Home Assistant version**: 2020.12.2

### Supervisor logs

title: Changing hostname in supervisor causes mDNS to not work
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

<!-- Provide as many details as possible. -->

When the hostname is changed, it is not possible to access the system via the URL with the hostname.  The system can only
be accessed via the URL with IP address.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Set up system with default hostname "homeassistant".
2. Point browser at http://homeassistant.local:8123  This works fine.
3. Navigate to Supervisor->System and change Hostname from "homeassistant" to "haos".
4. Reboot
5. Attempt to point browser at http://haos.local:8123 or http://haos:8123 or http://homeassistant.local:8123  None work, only IP address will work.
6. Point browser at http://192.168.1.X:8123 and log in again.  Change hostname back to "homeassistant".  Reboot.
7. Point browser at http://homeassistant.local:8123 and it works again.

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**: 5.9
- **Supervisor version:**: 2020.12.7
- **Home Assistant version**: 2020.12.2

title: 2020.12.7 Supervisor Memory Leak with Snapshots
body:
### Describe the issue

Supervisor memory usage grows with each snapshot, appears to be a leak.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->
```
~ $ ha su stats
blk_read: 523116544
blk_write: 11104256
cpu_percent: 0
memory_limit: 16676253696
memory_percent: 25.46
memory_usage: 4245491712
network_rx: 2110178930
network_tx: 1902095036
```
run Full Snapshot

```
~ $ ha su stats
blk_read: 523116544
blk_write: 11141120
cpu_percent: 0
memory_limit: 16676253696
memory_percent: 26.59
memory_usage: 4434001920
network_rx: 2110296157
network_tx: 1902316651
```

Taking the diff, Supervisor Memory grew by 188.510208 megabytes, a little over the reported size of the generated full snapshot (157MB)

HassOS on an Intel NUC, full details in System Info below

title: Missing files and folders in snapshot
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

<!-- Provide as many details as possible. -->
Im running automatic snapshots every night, and now i tried a manual snapshot to.
Everything seems to be fine untill i tried to restore the snapshot.
It's missing a couple of folders and files from the config folder.
And i guess it is because of the error in the supervisor log, that the snapshot somehow "finish" even if there is an error that makes the snapshot incomplete.
I have posted a topic in the community forum with more images to: [https://community.home-assistant.io/t/snapshot-missing-folders-and-files/259115](https://community.home-assistant.io/t/snapshot-missing-folders-and-files/259115)
### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. ...Make a manual snapshot
2. ...Download and extract it on my desktop computer
3. ...The folders: “image”, “packages”, “python_scripts” and “www” are for sure missing, and about 18 files in the root of config folder seems to be missing.

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**:  Home Assistant OS 5.9
- **Supervisor version:**: 2020.12.7

title: Error: Failed to fetch" when restoring snapshot on fresh install
body:
HassOS release with the issue:

QCOW2
2020.12.1

Supervisor logs:

Journal logs:

Kernel logs:

Description of problem:

Reinstalled HassOS in the clean version of Proxmox using hassos_ova-5.9.qcow2 and attempted to upload a snapshot and received a "Fail to fetch" notice. I have re installed Proxmox several times as well as Hassio. It will allow a new set up.

body:

### Describe the issue
I don't know if ingress is part of Core or Supervisor so i take my chance here.
I have just noticed that Ingress as starting giving error on my system.
I have noticed the issue by using 2 Addons: Nextcloud backup (https://github.com/Sebclem/hassio-nextcloud-backup) and Portainer.
If i look a the chrome log i can see this: 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23737709/102906359-cc55c400-4474-11eb-88c2-b8a736a6993d.png)

It seems to be random because some times the response is good.

title: Manual snapshot giving strange warning
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

Manual snapshot does not work. Automatic snapshots work fine.

About a minute after triggering a manual snapshot, the following message is reported in the Supervisor log:
`WARNING (MainThread) [supervisor.jobs] 'SnapshotManager.do_snapshot_full' blocked from execution, system is not running`

Might be related to the earlier reported issue #2328, but that is a guess, only.

Manual snapshots were working fine (albeit with the mysterious error message reported in issue #2328) as late as in HA 0.118.4.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Manually trigger a snapshot by clicking the CREATE button on the Supervisor->Snapshots page

title: Host System: IPv6 disabled makes Supervisor unable to save
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

While editing the `Host System` network details in Network settings Supervisor menu (i.e. changing DNS address in IPv4 connection), while having IPv6 Disabled, makes it unable to save the data.

Starting point (after edit of IPv4, leaving IPv6 disabled as it was):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6303489/102031327-eda01b80-3db5-11eb-954b-3803959bb40a.png)
after clicking 'Save':
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6303489/102031338-f7c21a00-3db5-11eb-89c5-f6213d06df97.png)
(translated: ipv6.method: property is invalid)

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Go to Supervisor -> System -> host System
2. Change anything but have IPv6 disabled 
3. Try to save

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**: Debian 10 Supervised / no issues reported by Supervisor
- **Supervisor version:**: 2020.12.6
- **Home Assistant version**: 2020.12.0

### Supervisor logs

<details>
<summary>Supervisor logs</summary>
<!--
- Frontend -> Supervisor -> System
- Or use this command: ha supervisor logs
- Logs are more than just errors, even if you don't think it's important, it is.
-->

```

```

</details>

title: last_changed error on device naming 0x000
body:
## Work fine on normal device
```
Last changed {{ states.binary_sensor.alarm_control_panel_armed.last_changed }}
``` 
```
Result: Last changed 2020-12-10 12:46:25.990941+00:00
```
---
## Not work on device name like this 0x086 (any zigbee2mqtt device)
```
Last changed {{ states.binary_sensor.0x086bd7fffeeec4b0_occupancy.last_changed }}
```
Result:
```
TemplateSyntaxError: expected token 'end of print statement', got 'x086bd7fffeeec4b0_occupancy'
```
---
## Make a binary device template and it work fine again
```
  sensors:
    contact_c300_tuya:
      device_class: door
      value_template: "{{ is_state('binary_sensor.0x086bd7fffeeec4b0_occupancy', 'on') }}"
```
```
Last changed {{ states.binary_sensor.contact_c300_tuya.last_changed }}
``` 
Result: 
```
Last changed 2020-12-10 12:46:25.990941+00:00
```

title: Supervised installation not working on Docker 20.x
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

Upgrading to the latest Debian 10 stable on 'healthy supported supervised' installation makes HA's components never come back again: supervisor, observer and all dockers including HA

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Have working Debian 10 installation
2. apt-get update && apt-get upgrade (docker-ce and containerd especially to version 20.x)
3. reboot (even it's not needed as dockers doesn't come back up)

After that, the only working 'docker ps' docker will be observer with no possibility to come back online.
restarting of the supervisor and doing `ha su repair` helps to get HA (and only HA, without addons) back online
But it's not persistent and lost after reboot.

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**: Debian 10.7
- **Supervisor version:**: latest (2020.12.06)
- **Home Assistant version**: latest (0.118.5)

### Supervisor logs

<details>
<summary>Supervisor logs</summary>
<!--
- Frontend -> Supervisor -> System
- Or use this command: ha supervisor logs
- Logs are more than just errors, even if you don't think it's important, it is.
-->

```
Supervisor doensn't come back up

```

</details>

### System Information

<details>
<summary>System Information</summary>
<!--
- Use this command: ha info
-->

```
arch: amd64
channel: stable
docker: 20.10.0
features:
- reboot
- shutdown
- services
- network
- hostname
hassos: null
homeassistant: 0.118.5
hostname: brix
logging: info
machine: qemux86-64
operating_system: Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster)
supervisor: 2020.12.6
supported: true
supported_arch:
- amd64
- i386
timezone: Europe/Warsaw

```

</details>

What's quick-fix for those that have their whole house down, is to downgrade docker:
`apt install docker-ce=5:19.03.14~3-0~debian-buster`
and restore full-snapshot...

EDIT:
Full rollback as in [alert](https://alerts.home-assistant.io/#docker_2010.markdown) until fixed:
```
apt install docker-ce=5:19.03.14~3-0~debian-buster
apt install docker-ce-cli=5:19.03.14~3-0~debian-buster
apt install containerd.io=1.3.9-1
```

title: Supervisor fails to recover from starting up without an internet connection
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

<!--
Important: You can only fill a bug repport for an supported system! If you run an unsupported installation. This report would be closed without comment.
-->

### Describe the issue

Supervisor fails to recover from starting up without an internet connection. When I reboot my entire network (powering down), often my Pi starts before my network is ready. When this happens, HA appears to be rightly reporting there is no internet connection however, when the network is back up... it does not detect the internet connection and does not recover from reporting no internet connection.

When this happens, I have to go into the HA UI and reboot HA once the internet connection has been established.
### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Power down entire network and including Pi
2. Start the pi back up
3. Power up your network again.

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

title: Unhealthy State / Unsupported OS
body:
### Describe the issue

Addon installs/changes/deletes, and supervisor upgrades blocked due to "unhealthy state". 
Investigating the errors/links provided by HASS showed a list of docker issues. These were all checked and are passing on my system (docker is latest version, no extra containers, etc). Additional messages state "unsupported OS". I'm running HASS Supervisor on a bare metal Arch Linux install, and have been for just under 18 months. 

### Steps to reproduce

Attempt to install or remove any addons. Attempt to update or downgrade HASS Supervisor/core. 

### Enviroment details

title: Issue: It looks like the new VLAN support doesn't work for Ethernet connections / interfaces
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

### Describe the issue
<!-- Provide as many details as possible. -->
I originally opened an issue about having an unsupported installation on HassOS due to Network Manager (https://github.com/home-assistant/operating-system/issues/933) which turned out to be caused by using a VLAN interface which eventually lead to adding support for VLANs to the supervisor here: https://github.com/home-assistant/supervisor/pull/2217.

The supervisor of my install recently got updated to version 2020.12.2 which looks to contain the new VLAN support. I noticed that under Supervisor->System->Host System block that it has an "IP Address" section with a "Change" link next to it but it doesn't show what my IP is (just blank / empty) where as when the test code changes noted in my original opened issue did show my actually IP address of my VLAN interface. Clicking on the "Change" link doesn't seem to do anything and as a side note, the supervisor doesn't say I'm running an unsupported installation like it did before version 2020.12.2

The supervisor logs do report an error (see below) which looks to me the way VLAN support was implemented was only for Wireless interfaces in that the error references my config is missing the "mode" attribute which looks to be related a WiFi NetworkManager option and that the VLAN interface uses wifi_struct.

The issue is in my case my VLAN config is on an Ethernet interface and not a Wireless one. I did try adding:
```
[wifi]
mode=infrastructure
```
to my NetworkManager config file for my VLAN Ethernet interface to see if that would work around he issue but that just prevented NetworkManager from bringing up the interface and thus no connection to the network.

### Steps to reproduce
<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->
1. Run a VLAN network configuration 
2. Supervisor gets auto updated to a version that in theory supports VLANs
3. Learn VLAN support doesn't seem to work with Ethernet interfaces

### Enviroment details
<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->
```

Installation Type	Home Assistant OS
Development	false
Supervisor	true

Update Channel	stable
Supervisor Version	2020.12.2
Docker Version	19.03.12
Disk Total	19.0 GB
Disk Used	10.4 GB
Healthy	true
Supported	true
Board	ova
Supervisor API	ok
Version API	ok
```

### Supervisor logs

<details>
<summary>Supervisor logs</summary>
<!--
- Frontend -> Supervisor -> System
- Or use this command: ha supervisor logs
- Logs are more than just errors, even if you don't think it's important, it is.
-->

```
20-12-03 14:56:14 ERROR (MainThread) [aiohttp.server] Error handling request
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/aiohttp/web_protocol.py", line 422, in _handle_request
    resp = await self._request_handler(request)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sentry_sdk/integrations/aiohttp.py", line 123, in sentry_app_handle
    reraise(*_capture_exception(hub))
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sentry_sdk/_compat.py", line 54, in reraise
    raise value

  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/aiohttp/web_app.py", line 499, in _handle
    resp = await handler(request)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/aiohttp/web_middlewares.py", line 118, in impl

    ATTR_VLAN: wifi_struct(interface.vlan) if interface.vlan else None,

AttributeError: 'VlanConfig' object has no attribute 'mode'
```

title: Installation in unhealthy state - ConnectivityCheckEnabled
body:
**Systems:**
- Odroid-XU4
- OS: DietPi v6.33.3 (based on Debian 9)
- Supervisor: 2020.12.2 (stable channel)
- Home-Assistant: 0.118.4
- All running on docker 19.03.13
- Connected via ethernet

**Info**

System Health

Home Assistant Core Integration

version: 0.118.4
installation_type: Home Assistant Supervised
dev: false
hassio: true
docker: true
virtualenv: false
python_version: 3.8.6
os_name: Linux
os_version: 4.14.180+
arch: armv7l
timezone: Europe/London

Home Assistant Cloud

logged_in: true
subscription_expiration: December 16, 2020, 12:00 AM
relayer_connected: true
remote_enabled: false
remote_connected: false
alexa_enabled: false
google_enabled: true
can_reach_cert_server: ok
can_reach_cloud_auth: ok
can_reach_cloud: ok

Hass.io

host_os: Debian GNU/Linux 9 (stretch)
update_channel: stable
supervisor_version: 2020.12.2
docker_version: 19.03.13
disk_total: 28.1 GB
disk_used: 14.6 GB
healthy: failed to load: Unhealthy
supported: failed to load: Unsupported
supervisor_api: ok
version_api: ok
installed_addons: Node-RED (7.2.11), Let's Encrypt (4.11.0), Mosquitto broker (5.1), ESPHome (1.15.3), MariaDB (2.2.1), InfluxDB (3.7.9), Samba share (9.3.0), Traccar (0.9.2), Grafana (5.3.6), phpMyAdmin (0.1.4), NGINX Home Assistant SSL proxy (3.0.1), File editor (5.2.0), Zigbee2mqtt (1.16.1), TasmoAdmin (0.13.1)

Lovelace

dashboards: 2
mode: storage
views: 11
resources: 2

**Problem**

Installation was carried out with the convenience script install.sh

Apart from the 'Unsupported OS', everything was running fine.

Today, the Supervisor started throwing out the following error:
"20-12-03 14:24:13 ERROR (MainThread) [asyncio] Task exception was never retrieved
future: <Task finished name='Task-374' coro=<HostManager.reload() done, defined at /usr/src/supervisor/supervisor/host/__init__.py:90> exception=KeyError('ConnectivityCheckEnabled')>
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/src/supervisor/supervisor/host/__init__.py", line 99, in reload
    await self.network.update()
  File "/usr/src/supervisor/supervisor/host/network.py", line 107, in update
    await self.check_connectivity()
  File "/usr/src/supervisor/supervisor/host/network.py", line 76, in check_connectivity
    if not self.sys_dbus.network.connectivity_enabled:
  File "/usr/src/supervisor/supervisor/dbus/network/__init__.py", line 58, in connectivity_enabled
    return self.properties[DBUS_ATTR_CONNECTION_ENABLED]
KeyError: 'ConnectivityCheckEnabled'"

I checked that Network-Manager was enabled, re-run the install.sh script without any issues.
I tried to manually set the IP via the Home-Assistant web interface and got a Error 500.

I am not 100% sure where else to look. If I understand the error correctly, the system indicates that it is not connected (to the internet?).

title: Wrong Low Space Notification Logic.
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

### Describe the issue

<!-- Provide as many details as possible. -->
The supervisor notification of low free space is bugged. I proceeded to delete and now have over 5Gb free, dismissed the notification and have restarted the server multiple times, and It keeps sending me the notification that space is low, but even quoting I have over 5 Gb free.

I believe what's happening is low space is being detected and stored, Maybe add some logic of checking if It's the case before notifying.

Here's a picture of the notification (clearly It's calculating free space well, but there's something wrong in the logic):
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9699804/100241269-82bf9b00-2f01-11eb-9c89-7607133ed621.png)


### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Get your installation to less than 1Gb of free space
2. Delete some stuff to get more than 1Gb space.
3. Dismiss the notification.
4. Wait for it to notify you again.

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**: HassOS 4.17
- **Supervisor version:**: 2020.11.0
- **Home Assistant version**: 0.118.2

### Supervisor logs

I can't find any logs about it.

<details>
<summary>Supervisor logs</summary>
<!--
- Frontend -> Supervisor -> System
- Or use this command: ha supervisor logs
- Logs are more than just errors, even if you don't think it's important, it is.
-->

```
Paste supervisor logs here

```

</details>

title: Local add-on: Connection reset by peer
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

### Describe the issue

<!-- Provide as many details as possible. -->
Hello. I've an issue with the local add-on.
My local addon is using ASP.NET Core 3.1 based image to run. I tested everything on my QNAP's Docker and it is working. Images are downloaded and container is working fine. But on the Home Assistant instance i have following window:
![local_addon1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22730088/99910955-7ebd2e80-2cf1-11eb-9537-1642ece15922.png)

Can you help me solve it?

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Create a new ASP.NET Core 3.1 project
2. Provide 'config.json' file into root folder
3. Copy the project into Home Assistant 'addons' folder
4. Reload local addons and try to install it

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**: HassOS 4.17 (RPi 3B)
- **Supervisor version:**: 2020.11.0
- **Home Assistant version**: 0.118.2

### Supervisor logs

<details>
<summary>Supervisor logs</summary>
<!--
- Frontend -> Supervisor -> System
- Or use this command: ha supervisor logs
- Logs are more than just errors, even if you don't think it's important, it is.
-->

```

20-11-22 17:30:55 INFO (SyncWorker_0) [supervisor.docker.addon] Starting build for local/armv7-addon-TestMe:0.2
20-11-22 17:30:55 ERROR (SyncWorker_0) [supervisor.docker.addon] Can't build local/armv7-addon-TestMe:0.2: ('Connection aborted.', ConnectionResetError(104, 'Connection reset by peer'))
```

title: Update Operating System to version null
body:
<!-- READ THIS FIRST:
- If you need additional help with this template please refer to https://www.home-assistant.io/help/reporting_issues/
- This is for bugs only. Feature and enhancement requests should go in our community forum: https://community.home-assistant.io/c/feature-requests
- Provide as many details as possible. Paste logs, configuration sample and code into the backticks. Do not delete any text from this template!
- If you have a problem with an add-on, make an issue in it's repository.
-->

### Describe the issue

<!-- Provide as many details as possible. -->

I installed HassOS on a virtual machine using the qcow2 image from https://www.home-assistant.io/hassio/installation/. I've provided the supervisor log which is available after the initial boot since I've already spotted an error message.

After the installation the supervisor dashboard shows an available update for the Operating System. Clicking on the enabled update button yields the following message: `Are you sure you want to update Operating System to version null?`

Confirming the update clicking on the update button results in the error message: `Unknown error, see supervisor`.
I've also provided the additional log entries after the described update procedure.

Similar behavior is also reported here: https://community.home-assistant.io/t/update-operating-system-to-version-null/241629 

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Install a VM using `virt-install --virt-type=kvm --name homeassistant --memory 2048 --vcpus=1 --os-variant=generic --network=bridge=br0,model=virtio --graphics none --disk path=/var/lib/libvirt/images/hassos_ova-4.16.qcow2 --import --boot uefi`
2. Go to http://xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx:8123/hassio/dashboard
3. Click on the update button for the OS.
4. Again, click on update.

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

title: supervised-installer script missing supported odroid-c4
body:
Hi,
Just a heads up in [home-assistant/supervised-installer ](https://github.com/home-assistant/supervised-installer)**installer.sh** na **README.md** should be updated to include **--machine odroid-c4**, according to [stable.json](https://version.home-assistant.io/stable.json) it is supported now.

title: Proxmox console (noVNC) keyboard no longer working
body:
### Describe the issue

Used to have access to the supervisor via the Console in Proxmox to run commands.  Around version 249, keyboard no longer works in noVNC. Weirdly, I actually see the cursor at the bottom of the console blinks slightly faster when I type...it's almost like its receiving keystrokes but not doing anything with them. 

Note: Clicking on Console on other VMs and typing works fine

Update: Actually I just got something to work. I mashed my keyboard and somehow that caused a poweroff command to be sent?!

### Steps to reproduce

1. Log into Proxmox
2. Click Console
3. Try and type
4. < nothing >

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8156439/97862511-644cf200-1cfd-11eb-85bc-8a2c5c714e8c.png)

### Environment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**: HassOS 4.15
- **Supervisor version:**: 249
- **Home Assistant version**: 0.117.2

title: Updating to 2020.10.0: Unit 'hassos-apparmor.service' not found
body:
### Describe the issue

<!-- Provide as many details as possible. -->

### Steps to reproduce

```
20-11-02 10:55:00 INFO (MainThread) [supervisor.host.apparmor] Adding/updating AppArmor profile: hassio-supervisor
20-11-02 10:55:00 ERROR (MainThread) [supervisor.host.services] Unit 'hassos-apparmor.service' not found
```

<!-- What do you do to encounter the issue. -->

1. Click update on the system tab
2. Error recieved

### Enviroment details

<!-- You can find these details in the system tab of the supervisor panel, or by using the `ha` CLI. -->

- **Operating System:**: HassOS 4.15
- **Supervisor version:**: 249
- **Home Assistant version**: 0.117.2

title: Change of add-on container image location, breaks update
body:
# Problem/Motivation

Add-ons could change download / image / dockerhub / container location. In this case, add-on updates will fail is the end-user has it installed already.

## Expected behavior

The update to happen without issues (d0h)

## Actual behavior

The add-on update will fail. Since Hass.io will try to download it from the "old" location since that is the configuration still loaded.

## Steps to reproduce

- Install an add-on
- After installation move the add-on to a new location on Dockerhub
- Update the add-on configuration
- Create a new release
- Try to update

## Proposed changes

Currently, Hassio only tracks the version to update. It should track the image as well.

## References

https://github.com/home-assistant/hassio/blob/e37ffd6107c909711eadcd5a9f906932ccd43815/hassio/addons/addon.py#L104

title: GPIO permission causes addon to fail on amd64 platforms
body:
I'm attempting to add GPIO permission to the Node-RED addon.  The addon works correctly on armhf, but the addon fails to start on amd64 because the host doesn't have `/sys/devices/platform/soc`.

```
18-04-06 19:10:33 ERROR (SyncWorker_7) [hassio.docker] Can't start addon_local_nodered: 500 Server Error: Internal Server Error ("error while creating mount source path '/sys/devices/platform/soc': mkdir /sys/devices/platform/soc: operation not permitted")
```

Is it possible to make the GPIO permission only apply to armhf platform or make it skip mapping GPIO if `/sys/devices/platform/soc` doesn't exist?

title: Refuses to build locally from specific images due to faulty regular expression
body:
# Problem/Motivation

Hassio local build seems to have a faulty regular expression in place, responsible for validating `build_from` images. This causes troubles with building an add-on locally within Hass.io/Home Assistant.

Example from a local build that fails:

```txt
[31m17-10-15 19:09:27 ERROR (SyncWorker_6) [hassio.tools] Can't parse /data/addons/local/addon-example/example/build.json -> does not match regular expression for dictionary value @ data['build_from']['aarch64']. Got 'hassioaddons/base-aarch64:1.0.0'
does not match regular expression for dictionary value @ data['build_from']['amd64']. Got 'hassioaddons/base-amd64:1.0.0'
does not match regular expression for dictionary value @ data['build_from']['armhf']. Got 'hassioaddons/base-armhf:1.0.0'
does not match regular expression for dictionary value @ data['build_from']['i386']. Got 'hassioaddons/base-i386:1.0.0'[0m
```

In the above case `hassioaddons/base-aarch64:1.0.0` is not accepted as a valid container name, while it is. I've been able to reproduce it with other containers as well, like `alpine:3.6`.

Currently used regular expression: `^[\-\w{}]+/[\-\w{}]+:[\-\w{}]+$`
Demo with missing matches: http://regexr.com/3gve8

## Proposed changes

Change the Voluptuous build config schema to allows for these images.

Change the regular expression to: `^([\-\w{}]+/)?[\-\w{}]+:[\-\.\w{}]+$`
Tests over here: https://regexr.com/3gve2
